Description: Corroded iron part of an implement, possibly a horse's snaffle-bit, made of three imbricated pieces; two fragments would correspond to the central part of the mouthpiece, made of two thin cylindrical bars ("cannons") jointed by loops interlocked and swiveling together, and possibly one shank made of a cylindrical bar with a central thickening around a socket threaded and sliding on one of the cannons. Ends of the cannons and shank are broken away.
Curator's comments: Considered as a possible bit in the Museum register, as fragment of a horses' bit, "riveted through cheek-pieces, as in figs. 5, 5a, 6", mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 77 § 77, p. 110. This item is similar, though larger, to London, BM, EA 23966 (op. cit., p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 5a). Other items from Tell Dafana considered as bridle-bits: London, BM, EA 23967, 23968 (op. cit., p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 1, 2), Cairo, EM, JE 27378 (lost), Boston, MFA 87.515 (op. cit., p. 77 § 77). Interpretation of London, BM, EA 23966, Boston, MFA, 87.516 (op. cit., p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 6), as well as London, BM, EA 23981, is more questionable.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 5)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.47, p.78, p.185, pl.27)
